contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Solomon" represents all the people with him. Also "came" can be stated as "went." Alternate translation: "So Solomon and the people with him went to Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-go]])
contextId.glQuote: So Solomon came to Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Huram represents all who worked on the temple. Alternate translation: "Huram and the other workers finished the work that they did" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Huram finished the work that he did

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Huram represents all who worked on the temple. Alternate translation: "Huram and the other workers had made" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: He had made

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Huram, who is also called Huram-Abi, represents all those who worked with him. Alternate translation: "They also made" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: He also made

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Huram, who is also called Huram-Abi, represents all those who worked with him. Alternate translation: "Huram-Abi and his craftsmen made" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Huram-Abi made

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon speaks of commanding the people to build the temple and telling them how to do it as if he himself had built it. Alternate translation: "I and your people have built you a lofty residence" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: I have built you a lofty residence

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon speaks of commanding the people to build the temple and telling them how to do it as if he himself had built it. Alternate translation: "this temple that your people have built under my leadership" or "this house that I and your people have built" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: this temple that I have built

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "head" refers to the whole person. Alternate translation: "on him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: upon his own head

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon speaks of commanding the people to build the temple and telling them how to do it as if he himself had built it. See how you translated a similar phrase in [2 Chronicles 6:18](../06/18.md). Alternate translation: "this house that your people have built under my leadership" or "this house that I and your people have built" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: this house I have built

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon speaks of commanding the people to build the temple and telling them how to do it as if he himself had built it. Alternate translation: "this house that your people have built under my leadership" or "this house that I and your people have built" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the house that I have built

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon speaks of commanding the people to build the temple and telling them how to do it as if he himself had built it. Alternate translation: "the house that your people have built under my leadership" or "the house that I and your people have built" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the house that I have built

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon represents his whole fighting army. Alternate translation: "Solomon's army attacked the town of Hamathzolbah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.glQuote: Solomon attacked Hamathzobah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Tadmor was a city north of Israel, in modern-day Syria. The author writes of Solomon commanding the people to build Tadmor as if Solomon himself built it. Alternate translation: "Solomon caused the town of Tadmor in the wilderness to be rebuilt" or "Solomon commanded, and the people built the town of Tadmor in the wilderness" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: He built Tadmor in the wilderness

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "my eyes" emphasizes that she herself saw it. Alternate translation: "now I have seen it for myself" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: now my eyes have seen it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hand" represents Shishak himself. Alternate translation: "by means of Shishak" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: by means of Shishak's hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The names of the kings represent the armies that they led. Alternate translation: "the wars in which Rehoboam's army and Jeroboam's army constantly engaged" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the constant wars between Rehoboam and Jeroboam

contextId.occurrenceNote: The names of the kings represent the armies that they led. Alternate translation: "There was war between the army of Abijah and the army of Jeroboam" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: There was war between Abijah and Jeroboam

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hands" represents the people who work. Alternate translation: "do not become weak as you work" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: do not let your hands be weak

contextId.occurrenceNote: The heart represents the person. Alternate translation: "Asa was completely devoted" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Asa's heart was completely devoted

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Asa's armies are represented by their commanders. Alternate translation: "sent his armies to attack the cities" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: sent the commanders of his armies against the cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Asa represents himself and his army. "his work" refers to other work that his workers were doing in Ramah. Alternate translation: "he commanded his army to stop fortifying Ramah and doing other work there" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.glQuote: he stopped building up Ramah, and let his work cease

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that king Asa's army was able to defeat the opposing army. Alternate translation: "he gave your army victory" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: he gave you victory

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jehoshaphat prepared the army for battle. Alternate translation: "prepared the army to be able to battle Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: strengthened himself against Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the king is represented by his "heart" to emphasize his will and desires. Alternate translation: "He" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: His heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Jehoshaphat represents his army. Alternate translation: "against Jehoshaphat's army" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: against Jehoshaphat

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here about refers to himself accompanied by his army as himself. Alternate translation: "should we not" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: should I not

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the kings represent themselves accompanied by their armies. Alternate translation: "Ahab, the king of Israel, and Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah led their armies up against" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Ahab, the king of Israel, and Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, went up against

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Jehoshaphat" represents himself and his army. Alternate translation: "came against Jehoshaphat's army to do battle" or "came to fight against Jehoshaphat and his army" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: came against Jehoshaphat to do battle

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh's presence is represented by his "name." Alternate translation: "your presence is here in this house" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: your name is in this house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people are represented by their "eyes" to emphasize that they are directing their attention to God. Alternate translation: "we are looking to you for help" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: our eyes are on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a reference to every man in the army. Alternate translation: "every soldier of Judah and Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: every man of Judah and Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Other people helped Jehoram build these high places all over the mountains of Judah. Alternate translation: "Jehoram and the people had also built high places" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Jehoram had also built high places

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Jehoram refers to Jehoram and the people of Judah that he ruled. Alternate translation: "against Jehoram and the people of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: against Jehoram

contextId.occurrenceNote: The reader should understand that Hazael did not fight alone, but that he took his army with him. Alternate translation: "to fight against Hazael, king of Aram, and his army" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: to fight against Hazael, king of Aram

contextId.occurrenceNote: Uzziah did not do this alone. Alternate translation: "It was he who ordered Elath to be rebuilt" or "It was he who supervised the rebuilding of Elath" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: It was he who rebuilt Elath

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Uzziah" represents himself and his army that he led. Alternate translation: "Uzziah led his army out to fight against the Philistines" or "Uzziah and his army went out and fought against the Philistines" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Uzziah went out and fought against the Philistines

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the pronouns "He" and "him" represent Uzziah and his army. Alternate translation: "Uzziah and his army broke down ... they built cities" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: He broke down ... he built cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the pronouns "He" and "him" represent Uzziah and his army. Alternate translation: "God helped them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: God helped him

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to translate so that the reader understands that Jothan led his army to fight. Alternate translation: "He also led his army to fight with the king of the people of Ammon" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: He fought also with the king of the people of Ammon

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to translate so that the reader understands that the king of Ammon led his army to fight. Alternate translation: "with the king of Ammon and his army" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: with the king of the people of Ammon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "heart" represents the person who was willing. Alternate translation: "who were willing" or "who desired" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: who had a willing heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ephraim and Manasseh were two of the tribes in the northern part of Israel. Here the phrase "Ephraim and Manasseh" refers to the people who belonged to all ten of the northern tribes of Israel. Alternate translation: "the northern tribes of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Ephraim and Manasseh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ephraim and Manasseh were two of the tribes in the northern part of Israel. Here the phrase "Ephraim and Manasseh" refers to the people who belonged to all ten of the northern tribes of Israel. See how you translated it in [2 Chronicles 30:1](../30/01.md). Alternate translation: "the regions of the northern tribes of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the regions of Ephraim and Manasseh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Sennacherib represents his army. Alternate translation: "Sennacherib, king of Assyria, and his army came ... They camped" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Sennacherib, king of Assyria, came ... He camped

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Sennacherib also represents his army. Alternate translation: "that Sennacherib and his army had come and that they intended" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: that Sennacherib had come and that he intended

contextId.occurrenceNote: The readers should understand that Hezekiah probably commanded other people to do the actual work. Alternate translation: "Hezekiah took courage and commanded the people to build up ... They built ... They also ... they made" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Hezekiah took courage and built up ... He built ... He also ... he made

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Jerusalem" is a part of "Judah." Alternate translation: "the people of Judah and Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: The commanders were accompanied by their soldiers. Alternate translation: "the commanders of the army of the king of Assyria and their soldiers" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the commanders of the army of the king of Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to some on the money that was entrusted to Hilkiah. Alternate translation: "some of the money" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the money

contextId.occurrenceNote: The supervisors and workmen are represented by their "hand" to emphasize their possession. Alternate translation: "to the supervisors and the workmen" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: into the hand of the supervisors and to the workmen

contextId.occurrenceNote: "to Jerusalem" This refers to the city of Jerusalem which represents the whole land of Judah. Alternate translation: "on Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: on this place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "eyes" represents the whole person. Also, the phrase "will not see" represents not experiencing something. Alternate translation: "you will not experience" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: your eyes will not see

contextId.occurrenceNote: Josiah's life is represented by his "days." Alternate translation: "For all of his life" or "As long as Josiah was alive" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: For all of his days

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hand" refers to Moses himself. Yahweh used Moses as the agent to deliver his command. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: "to obey all of the commands that Yahweh gave to the people through Moses" or "to do everything that Yahweh commanded Moses to tell the people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: to do according to the word of Yahweh that was given by the hand of Moses

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hand" refers to the Levites. Alternate translation: "the blood that the Levites gave them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the blood that they received from the Levites' hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here both Josiah and Necho represent themselves accompained by their armies. Alternate translation: "Josiah and his army went to fight against Necho and his army" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Josiah went to fight against him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the king Josiah represents his kingdom. Alternate translation: "I am not fighting your kingdom" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: I am not coming against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "him" refers to Necho who represents himself accompanied by his army. Alternate translation: "fight with the army of Egypt" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: fight with him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God is represented by his "mouth" to emphasize his speech. Alternate translation: "that had come from God" or "that God had said to him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: that had come from the mouth of God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "he" refers to Josiah who represents himself accompanied by his army. Alternate translation: "so he and his army went" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: so he went

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the noun "word" can be translated with the verb "spoke." The word "mouth" represents Jeremiah. Alternate translation: "what Yahweh spoke through Jeremiah" or "the word from Yahweh that Jeremiah spoke" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the word of Yahweh by the mouth of Jeremiah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the noun "word" can be translated with the verb "spoke." The word "mouth" represents Jeremiah. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "so that what Yahweh spoke through Jeremiah might happen" or "so that the word from Yahweh that Jeremiah spoke might happen" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: so that the word of Yahweh by the mouth of Jeremiah might be carried out

contextId.occurrenceNote: Motivating the spirit is a synecdoche for making someone want to act. Alternate translation: "Yahweh made Cyrus, king of Persia, want to act" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh motivated the spirit of Cyrus, king of Persia
